awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through the development of highly competitive students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaska Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  The goal of the LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Activity is to increase the quantity and quality of STEM graduate students from underrepresented populations, with emphasis on PhD matriculation and completion.  BD programs implemented in the nation's institutions of higher education contribute to addressing one of the objectives in NSF's 2018-2022 Strategic Plan, namely to "foster the growth of a more capable and diverse research workforce and advance the scientific and innovation skills of the Nation."  The vision of this grant is to provide a national model to produce underrepresented scientists and engineers with doctoral degrees in STEM.

The performance site for this LSAMP BD activity is the University of Virginia (UVA), one of the 12 partners included in the Virginia-North Carolina Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (VA-NC LSAMP).  UVA, the lead institution for the alliance, will host the first BD program for VA-NC LSAMP; providing doctoral-level study for a cohort of 12 graduates from LSAMP undergraduate programs.  In addition to affording substantial financial support to enable students to focus full time on doctoral course work and research, the project provides an integrated set of activities designed to advance BD students toward completion of doctoral level studies.  Activities include: 1) a 3-week summer bridge enrichment program; 2) professional development opportunities; 3) training and preparation of applications for competitive graduate fellowships; and 4) extracurricular mentoring support that prepares the students to become STEM professionals.  These activities address barriers that limit the increase of students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields, particularly at the doctoral level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate: University of Virginia, Virginia-North Carolina Alliance (2018-2023)

Project Outcomes Report

The Virginia-North Carolina Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (VA-NC  Alliance) Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) at the University of Virginia (UVA) received funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) for $1,075,000 starting August 1, 2018, and ending July 31, 2023.  The BD program's primary goal was to increase the quantity and quality of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) graduate students from underrepresented populations (as defined by NSF), emphasizing PhD completion. The BD management team and advisory board recruited fellows from Alliances throughout the nation to complete its cohort of 12 graduate students. The VA-NC Alliance BD cohort at UVA cohort included: Yonathan Aberra, David Crowe, Cesar Garcia, Cami Keliinui, Natalie Lerma, Lorenzo Ortiz, Roberto Herrera del Valle, Taylor Patrick, Rossymar Rivera-Colon, Yadeliz Serrano Matos, Jamel Simpson, and Coleman Tolliver. Despite the impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic that coincided with the BD fellows' time in their graduate programs, at the time of this project outcomes report, one BD fellow had defended his dissertation and earned his Ph.D. in Materials Science & Engineering while three had earned a Master of Teaching - Science, a Master of Science in Materials Science & Engineering, and a Master's in Biological & Physical Science.

The BD program at UVA has supported cohort members in earning their STEM graduate degrees through financial support for the fellows' stipends, tuition, and fees. The BD program also provided activities designed to enhance the fellows' graduate student experiences, including orientation, bridge curricula as needed, one-on-one meetings with BD program director Dr. Keisha John, professional development opportunities, preparation to apply for graduate research fellowships, mentoring, and social events. Finally, Each BD fellow and faculty mentor were required to develop and then update on an annual basis at minimum, an Individualized Development Plan (IDP).

While the BD did not offer a formal bridge component, it allowed schools and faculty mentors the flexibility to design curricula to meet individual needs. For instance, the School of Medicine's Biomedical Sciences Program created a bridge curriculum specific to the needs of one of its incoming fellows. That student then transitioned to core classes with the additional preparation and pre-requisites.

The BD program offered fellows a few signature, professional development activities: 1) mentoring, 2) PhD Plus, 3) writing workshops, and 4) support for presentations at national conferences. The UVA Office for Graduate and Postdoctoral Affairs (OGPA) organized the Mentoring Institute that matched interested BD fellow with a STEM faculty mentor outside of their discipline to promote networking and establish an external department champion who would help with the transition into graduate studies and life in Charlottesville. BD fellows also participated in PhD Plus activities, a university-wide initiative offering activities and trainings to PhD students and postdoctoral scholars to prepare them for their long-term career success (https://phdplus.virginia.edu/). Moreover, the BD management team offered writing support through small group and one-on-one consultation for assistance with papers and/or dissertations. Finally, the management team offered some financial support for participation in conferences.  Four students presented their research at or attended national conferences.

Furthermore, BD fellows had opportunities to serve as informal mentors to current undergraduate student researchers. Five of the BD fellows interacted with participants in the VA-NC Alliance Summer Research Program and/or the Annual VA-NC Alliance Undergraduate Research Symposium through serving as a judge for oral presentations and/or participating in a graduate student panel. As former LSAMP undergraduate students, this near-peer mentoring experience gave BD fellows the experience of serving as a mentor in preparation for their future faculty or other professional roles.

The Alliance management team communicated regularly with BD fellows via email and phone about funding and presentation opportunities, as well as social and professional development-related events, and posted these on the LSAMP.VIRGINIA.EDU graduate school webpage. The BD advisory board met regularly for the first three years of the program, then communicated as needed for the remainder of the program.

The knowledge contributed by the fellows to their respective STEM disciplines demonstrated the intellectual merit of the BD program and has been reflected in their presentations at national conferences, journal articles, and dissertations and theses.

The BD program had a broader impact by increasing the quality and quantity of underrepresented graduate students in STEM fields. Through their graduate education and professional development experiences, the BD fellows have been well-prepared to succeed in the STEM workforce and contribute to meeting the critical need for a more diverse labor force.
